verses.text: LORD, you showed favor to your land; you restored the fortunes of Jacob.
verses.comment: This verse recalls God bringing His people back from exile and restoring their blessings. 'Jacob' is a poetic term for Israel. The restoration of Israel prefigures God’s ultimate act of salvation fulfilled in Christ, who restores humanity in an even greater way.

verses.text: You forgave the guilt of your people; you covered all their sin. Selah.
verses.comment: 'Covered all their sin' uses language that points towards atonement. In the Old Testament, sin was covered by sacrifice, yet in the New Testament, sins are taken away entirely by Christ’s sacrifice (Heb. 10:4, 10:10). The word 'Selah' indicates a pause for reflection.

verses.text: You withdrew all your wrath; you turned from your fierce anger.
verses.comment: God’s mercy tempers His justice, as seen throughout salvation history. This verse anticipates how God’s anger is ultimately appeased through reconciliation, which is completed perfectly in Christ (Rom. 5:10).

verses.text: Restore us again, God of our salvation, and put away your anger toward us.
verses.comment: 'Restore us' is a recurring prayer in the Psalms (cf. Ps. 80), indicating the people’s dependence on God for spiritual renewal. This daily continual restoration points to the ongoing process of sanctification in the believer’s life.

verses.text: Will you be angry with us forever? Will you prolong your wrath through all generations?
verses.comment: The psalmist questions God, acknowledging His righteousness but appealing to His mercy. Throughout salvation history, though God may chastise, His mercy never fails (see Ps. 103:9).

verses.text: Will you not revive us again, so that your people may rejoice in you?
verses.comment: The plea for revival asks God to breathe new life into His people. This has spiritual implications—the continual action of the Spirit reviving the Church, fulfilling Jesus’ words about sending the Spirit as the Comforter (Jn. 14:26).

verses.text: Show us your faithful love, LORD, and grant us your salvation.
verses.comment: God’s faithful love (Hebrew: hesed) and salvation are joined. The fullness of this love is most clearly shown in the person and work of Christ, who brings eternal salvation (Tit. 3:4-6).

verses.text: I will hear what God the LORD will say, for he promises peace to his people, his faithful ones; but let them not turn back to folly.
verses.comment: This verse emphasizes listening to God’s word. God’s peace (shalom) is granted to those who are faithful and remain in relationship with Him. Turning away from sin is essential for preserving peace—a principle underlining the importance of repentance and ongoing conversion (cf. Heb. 3:12-15).

verses.text: Surely his salvation is near those who fear him, that glory may dwell in our land.
verses.comment: 'Glory may dwell in our land' anticipates the coming of God’s presence among His people, fulfilled ultimately in the Incarnation (Jn. 1:14). Fearing God is not just about reverence—but living in accordance with His ways, preparing the way for His indwelling.

verses.text: Steadfast love and faithfulness meet; righteousness and peace kiss each other.
verses.comment: This poetic imagery describes the unity of God’s attributes, ultimately fulfilled in Christ crucified, where justice and mercy are perfectly joined (Rom. 3:25-26). In the life of the Church, these virtues are to be reflected among the faithful.

verses.text: Faithfulness springs up from the earth, and righteousness looks down from the heavens.
verses.comment: There is a sense of union: humanity’s faithfulness and God’s righteousness meeting, fulfilled as heaven and earth are joined in Christ’s coming. The people’s response of faith is met by divine initiative.

verses.text: Yes, the LORD will give what is good, and our land will yield its harvest.
verses.comment: Physical blessings, like fruitful land, are signs of God’s favor but also prefigure spiritual abundance—sacramental life and grace that God continues to pour out on His people (Jn. 6:35; 2 Cor. 9:10).

verses.text: Righteousness will go before him and will make his footsteps a way.
verses.comment: Righteousness preparing the way points toward John the Baptist’s call to prepare for the Lord’s coming (Isa. 40:3; Matt. 3:3). Christ walks the path of righteousness first, and His people are called to follow in His ways, participating in the fullness of His life and grace.
